segments.text: convinced they made this one out of the battleship arizona all right now uh in addition to the italians not being too concerned about about the impact of of their civilization on the environment are there any other particular european countries which uh seem to have a like attitude well when you get up into the baltic
you find a situation which, in my opinion, represents almost the end of the curve.

That whole industrial area along the Baltic, which includes both Germany's Soviet Union, the Scandinavian countries, Belgium, the Netherlands, they've been dumping just about everything into the rivers farther up that comes down and dumps into either the Baltic or the North Sea.
And if you look at some of the rivers there as they enter the seas, they defy the imagination.
If we think we have polluted rivers, we ain't seen nothing.
And the public is beginning to get concerned.
There's a situation in Sweden, for example, where the fallout from sulfites in the atmosphere has reduced the pH acidity of the Swedish lake
Many of the very productive fishing lakes are now completely destroyed.
And, of course, they blame it on their neighbors to the south, which is where it's coming from.
But it's so complicated with so many different countries living so closely together as to who to blame what, and there's not much point in one country trying to clean up the river at its...
if the country upstream is going to continue to pollute it.
So it's a far more complicated situation than we have here.
A lot of laymen are concerned about it, but they don't have the machinery or the platform from which to work that we do in this country to get the government to do something.
Okay, I only have one more question about the environment and your work in environmentalism.
And that is, is there any hope
for environmentalism in underdeveloped countries at all?
Yes, and it's for that reason that we are involved right now in the planning of an international workshop in Brazil next year to try to bring to their attention, at their request pretty much,
The problems involved with planning and pollution and biological productivity in coastal environments and estuarine environments.

Many of the government officials in a state like Bahia, the governor of which incidentally is a graduate of the medical school of Cornell and extremely knowledgeable and extremely concerned about the collision course that Bahia is on,
in reference to tourism, petrochemical industries, and fisheries.
He sees that they cannot develop all three without considering the weaknesses and liabilities of each one of them.
And we want to join with them and people from all over Latin America and hopefully Europe to talk about the things that we have done, the mistakes that we have made,
we might do if we were going to do it again and hopefully catch them early enough on the slope of their curve that they can do some of the things within reason.

Now you're not going to, I'm not going to expect them to do much to retard the development of the petrochemical complex down there which is a multi-billion dollar program in the interest of a few fish.
But I think the fact that they are even concerned about it is rewarding.
And most of the younger staff within the planning division, which is sort of like our EPA, are educated in this country or Europe.
And they're knowledgeable.
And they just need some guidance and some examples of things to help them develop their own program.
Other countries, no.
But a lot of Latin American countries are really concerned.
that they're going to wreck what they've got before they ever really begin to enjoy it.
Now I have a series of questions which may or may not be true.
These are simply things I don't know.
Did you ever study at Scripps Institution of Oceanography?
No.
Did you do work out there as a research associate?
No.
I visited there once as a member of the Ocean Sciences Board of the National Academy of Sciences.
That's all.
Why has so much of your larval development and growth research been done on the barnacle?
Well, I wouldn't say it has been.
I might have agreed with that 10 years ago.
But since then, we've taken a lot of the techniques that we developed for barnacles and expanded it in other ways.
And which ways have you expanded?
Primarily into the decapod crustaceans, the crabs and the shrimps, but some into polychaetes and some other crustaceans.
Okay, now, when I went back and read your articles, it seemed to me that the move to the crab, the significant move to the crab, came in 65 and 66.
Would you disagree with that?
No, it was a little earlier.
Okay.
About 60, actually.
Okay, well, the first time I begin to see a goodly number of publications appear is the middle 60s.
Yeah, well, by that time, the numbers, and that tied in with O&R London, just as a side here.
I was invited to go to O&R London, and the date that we could agree upon was 65, and I looked at the things I had to get finished before I could go, and I said, okay.
And I worked up a big data sheet of titles of manuscripts,
And I just settled down and wrote for months.
That's why there was a sudden rush.
All right, good.
All of a sudden, I've got a sudden burst of things coming out on blue crabs and so forth, and I couldn't figure out where they came from.
That's why.
They seem to come from no place, haven't they?
Okay.
I wanted to get it all done before I went to Illinois.
I didn't, but I got a lot of it done.
What has been some of your significant findings in the field of Louisville development?
If you just had to cite several significant things you discovered, what would you cite for yourself?
Okay, first, the development of techniques which permit their culture in the laboratory under controlled conditions.
Secondly, an understanding of the way in which the environment
through one and two, making available large numbers, thousands of larval stages of known age and species for a variety of other experimental purposes.
And then for the beginnings of an understanding of the hormonal mechanisms which regulate development in a fashion similar to the insects.
How well do we know the feeding habits of various crustaceous lovers, by the way?
Well enough to permit us to culture them, but when you get into the real nitty-gritty lurid details, there's still quite a great deal that could be learned if someone were sufficiently interested.
Do you know enough for culture already?
Oh, yeah.
Have you thought of your studies of larval development, have you done it specifically to aid general knowledge, or have you thought of it in terms of your work in coastal management and aquaculture?
Well, originally it was to provide a better understanding of development.
I think all of us, when we are younger,
And we're more concerned about the quest for knowledge.
And then as you get a little bit older, you begin to realize that knowledge in itself, while it's desirable, is far more desirable if it has some use.
And the sooner you can put it to good use, to me, the more rewarding it is.
So that the fact that we are now able to use larvae as bioassay indicators for extremely
I had 10 years ago, as an example.
I now have a series of what amount to sort of standard questions on which I want opinions on.
100% unguaranteed opinions, if you should like them.
First of all, what do you consider your major accomplishment as a scientist?
Well, I hope I haven't made it yet.

I guess thus far, serving as director of this institution during its expansion phase, because in so doing I contributed to other people developing research programs, and that's the function of a director.
All right, well that anticipates my next four questions, so let me just follow right with these.
First of all, how do you explain
your tremendous flurry of expansion in the 1960s for the lab here.
Was it ONR and outside source funds or what?

Well, it was primarily because Bookhouse saw a number of the things that are developing now well before they developed and began the necessary planning and, if you will, education of university officials.
to be prepared for it, and also developing a sound academic, educational, intellectual base on which to do this expansion.
For example, in 62 or 63, Bookie became very concerned because biological oceanographers, especially those from smaller institutions, found it almost impossible to get ship time.
I won't say why.

And he convinced the National Science Foundation that they should fund the design and construction and management of a cooperative oceanographic vessel, which would give the biological oceanographers from the small institutions 10 days of ship time completely free.
Well, 10 years later, well, in the meantime,

At the same time, to avoid bias and empire building, he insisted that it be coordinated by a seven-man committee, only one of whom could be from Duke, so that even though on paper we own the vessel, we can't run it in the selfish sense.
Okay, ten years later, this concept evolved into UNOLS.
University National Oceanographic Laboratory System for the running of all federally sponsored and funded oceanographic vessels in the United States.
Well, Buckey was 10 years ahead of his time on that one and on a number of other things.
He saw the fact that this laboratory would become more actively involved in a number of things and that we would have a need for expanded facilities, we would have a need for expanded staff,

And it was about the time that this was agreed upon by the university, the National Science Foundation, in 67, that I came along as the director, so I have served as the director in the interim of this expansion.
Now, secondly, why were you chosen as director?
Let me warn you in advance, this question is loaded.

Having myself come through large universities where I've gone back to teach, it's highly unusual for a man with his degree from a university to even return to the university, much less head the major establishment of marine biology at the university.
How do you explain that?
Well, I thought about it, and you know, I never will really know.
The fight over inbreeding occurred earlier.
In 59, actually while I was away on a leave of absence in Scotland, the Department of Zoology was approached about appointing me as an assistant professor, book out having made the recommendation.
And I am told, of course I wasn't here, and maybe it's just as well, I'm told that there was a real knock down, drag out fight
within the department over this question of inbreeding.
For reasons that I will never know, the university decided to do it anyway.
So that by the time the 67 appointment came around, that issue had already been decided.
And I assume that the university, in looking at potential candidates for the job, saw in me a person who was already settled in Beaufort and therefore
apparently compatible with a small town.
I had been the mayor of the town for two terms.
I had been involved in all sorts of public endeavors like school bond referendum and that sort of thing.
My academic record, other than teaching, for which I was not employed, was acceptable in terms of publication, involvement with national and international things.
My administrative capacity had only been viewed through the management of research grants, of which I had at one time four or five.
And I assumed that putting all those things together, they decided that rather than betting on a new horse, they would take a chance and bet on one that they knew.
But that's all speculation, because nobody's ever told me.

have you discovered as administrator or chief administrator of the lab here, have you discovered interpersonal relationships in the academic world have been particularly difficult or easy for you in direction of the lab?
You better state the last phrase of that.
Okay.
As an administrator, have you found it difficult to...
give direction to the laboratory and also continue to have interpersonal relationships with your faculty.
Oh, not yet for the most part.
But I think it's in part because I am an administrator secondly.
I still think of myself as a scientist first and it's for that reason that I continue to spend as much time as I can doing research, publishing.
And it's for this reason that I continue to accept financial support for research, because I feel I am obligated to do it if I've been given money to do it.
I know people who are administrators first, and that's where you get in trouble.
OK, now that's the fourth question.
An interview I just had with Nirenberg, and I'm sure he wouldn't object to me using his name, he maintained that he had essentially given up research

And he saw his role in the future, not as a researcher writing any more papers or doing this kind of thing, but as continuing to give direction to Scripps Institution of Oceanography, which he thought would be his major contribution to the scientific world.
I take it from reading your publication list, you don't see your role that way.
Is that a fair statement?
It is a fair statement.
And I think you've got to keep several things in mind.
The facility that he administers is considerably larger.
Yes.
and I can see why it would be constantly threatening what little time he might have had left for research.
This institution in my lifetime will never approach the size of his, in part by coincidence and in part because we don't want it to.
We operate on the theme that a university facility like this functions best in some nebulous size range which we've not really defined.
But the relationship between staff and students, students and students, is so important here that we don't want it to be the size of something that he's dealing with.
So it's a different ballgame entirely.
I am concerned about any person who gives direction to science
on the basis of information which is either secondhand or obsolete.
And I have seen in some number of the U.S. government agencies directors of scientific programs who had their last real excursion with science in 1947.
Their knowledge of today's frontiers are primarily 1947 ideas.
And the direction that you get out of that sort of information is downhill.
So that I will only continue to serve as director of this laboratory as long as provisions are made for me to have some time for research.
And if that day does not, if the day comes when that is not possible, then somebody else can be director.
I was going to ask you about the size of the institution.
You've already answered that.
Now I want to ask you about the students at the institution.
Do you try to take primarily students from your own university?
Or do you try to solicit applicants from elsewhere in the state and outside the state?
Well, when Doc Kearse developed this place in 38, it was with Duke University in mind.
And that soon became apparent that this was not realistic.
because it began to attract students from other institutions.
So that I inherited a tradition developed over almost 40 years of serving as a national laboratory insofar as marine training is concerned.
And this has been expanded because some number of people at Duke
over the years, have finished degrees with some involvement here, have gone out to institutions all over the United States, many of which did not have marine programs.
If a student at their own institution comes to them for advice as to where to go for a program in marine biology, oceanography, they automatically send them here.
they in turn go out to other institutions, so the whole thing builds up to a feedback mechanism.
And that's where we are now.
The gentleman teaching the marine invertebrate zoology course this summer at Beaufort is Robert Barnes, author of most likely the best-known text on invertebrate zoology in the world.
He's a Duke Ph.D.
He and I were roommates together as graduate students.
I guess it's the old boy syndrome.
sure that one of the reasons Bob came back is that he enjoys teaching here.
Some number of students came to that course this summer because he's teaching here.
And they will provide further feedback in 1983, 4, 5, and 6.
We have expanded that traditional role to the international realm.
And we're now in the third year of our so-called international training program, which I mentioned earlier.
That will, in time, provide us with feedback
from all over the world.
And I think this is a very vital role that this laboratory can play as a facility of a privately endowed university.
We are totally apart from any real political influence.
And I think we have a responsibility that goes with that.
Then you see your direction of this institution as more and more of a cosmopolitan.
Very definitely.

In giving leadership of sorts, if I may use that word, I'm not trying to imply that you gave total direction to the lab, but in giving leadership of sorts to the lab, were there any distinctive goals you had in mind when you took over your position?
Yeah, to expand, well, remember that I inherited the situation where we knew that
affiliated with the laboratory.

This meant expanding the opportunities for students, expanding the facilities to accommodate those students who would be coming, and developing a far more interdisciplinary program than we had at that time.
And that has led in turn to the greater involvement on the international realm, drawing on my own connections from the days of ONR and others.
But we have had some number of objectives which are pretty well taken care of now.
And now it's primarily a question of making certain that in becoming somewhat larger, we do not lose the quality which we like to think we have.
Now that's the next question.
What sort of directions do you foresee for your institution in the future?
Well, as a facility of a university, some of that is already predetermined in the sense that we have as a major role the education of what we call senior and graduate level students.
So that we must constantly be aware of what the trends are to provide the necessary coursework to prepare the students for those trends.
maintaining a reasonable quality.
And my own personal interest leans toward a further involvement insofar as the international community is concerned, but doing the same thing.
So all we're doing is increasing the involvement, but not changing the program itself.
Yeah.
The assumption usually is, as the program grows larger and as the institution grows larger, that you tend to look for more specialized students.
That is, people who are not oceanography undergraduates or what have you, but people who have a special science they can bring into the community, like marine zoology and so forth.
Has this been your policy here?
Well, the expansion that we have just finished,
it became a separate inter-institutional facility, or rather inter-departmental facility of the university with resident staff from six of potentially seven different departments.
So we have people here who are affiliated with departments in biochemistry, geology, botany, zoology, chemistry, and physiology med school.
So that here is a very broad base from which to develop research programs, training programs, student involvement at either the state, national, or international level.
And we've already begun to develop that.
And I assume we will continue to.
But we don't look for the development of people to know more and more about less and less in terms of one very narrow program.
As some labs do, especially some of the European labs, if the professor has an interest in the third setos hair on the fourth abdominal appendage, then that's what they become known for.
Well, that's not our interest at all.
We want to have a broad base which will provide the proper research facilities, experience, and training for people who will go out and send their students back here.
And I think that you see your role in oceanography, at least in the near future, as to continue to administer the lab.
Well, insofar as Duke is concerned, yeah.
I will continue to peck away at my own research interests relative to larval dispersal, larval development, oceanic dispersal.
and continue to serve hopefully in a number of capacities insofar as the U.S. is concerned, the National Oceanographic Program, and continue to expand the international aspects.
And all of these relate to oceanography, even though we're situated in the backwater of both.
